title:
Systematic study of confinement induced effects on atomic electronic
  structure
abstract:
We point out that although a litany of studies have been published on atoms
in hard-wall confinement, they have either not been systematic, having only
looked at select atoms and/or select electronic configurations, or they have
not used robust numerical methods. To remedy the situation, we perform in this
work a methodical study of atoms in hard-wall confinement with the HelFEM
program, which employs the finite element method (FEM) that trivially
implements the hard-wall potential, guarantees variational results, and allows
easily finding the numerically exact solution.
  We systematically examine low lying configurations of the H-Xe atoms and
their monocations, and investigate how the states - especially the ground state
- behave as a function of the position of the hard-wall boundary. Our fully
numerical calculations are based on non-relativistic density functional theory
(DFT), employing the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation
functional and spherically averaged densities. We consider calculations with
both spin-polarized as well as spin-restricted densities, and demonstrate that
spin-polarization effects are significant in open shell configurations, even
though some previous studies have only considered the spin-restricted model.
  We demonstrate the importance of considering ground state changes for
confined atoms by computing the ionization radii for the H-Xe atoms and observe
significant differences to earlier studies. Confirming previous observations,
we identify electron shifts on the outermost shells for a majority of the
elements: valence $s$ electrons are highly unfavored under strong confinement,
and the high-lying $3d$ and $4f$ orbitals become occupied in atoms of periods
2-3 and 4, respectively.
